THE NEWS-LETTER.

TO ALGERNON CHARLES SW1NBURNE.
APRIL 5th, 1908.
Sovereign of song, a welcome today across the rolling sea
I send in greeting to you on this happy morn of Spring;
Another year has past away, and still we look in love to thee
As one who gives forth song and makes the wildernesses sing,
As one, who since his youth-time,
In gladness and in ruth-time,
In anger and in passion, in hate, in love, in praise,
Has given us full measure
Of unalloyed pleasure
By ceasely song and music through the full-time of his days.
The full three-score of years and ten rested on you a year ago,
Then from the corners four of all the world you beard
Our messages of reverence, from rich and poor, from high and low—
A message comprehended in a single, perfect word—
A word, whose meaning yearly,
Through all your lifetime clearly,
You have expounded to the world and placed all words above—
Which now in reverence duly
And admiration truly
I send to you—a perfect gift—a radiant message—Love!
Take this, my gift from o'er the seas, and in thy home among the Pines
Think for a moment of a heart which has a love for thee—
Who, midst the dreams of boyhood, in admiration, in these lines
Has written here his love for you, the Poet o'er the sea.
But though the sea divide us
There ever is beside its
One bond—here and in England—a bond we share among
Two nations far asunder;
And, yet, the broad seas under,
There runs the common, glorious tie—the bond of Shakespeare's tongue.
S. C. C.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

THE KEATS-SHELLEY MEMORIAL IN
ROME.
DOLLAR SUBSCR PTIONS INVITED FROM
UNDERGRADUATES.
March, 1908.

To the Professor of English Poetry:
The fund for the purchase of the Keats
House in Rome lacks about $1,500, which it
is desirable to raise at once. As Secretary of
the informal American Committee, which in
the death of Mr. Stedman has lost its. devoted
Chairman, I am inviting the co-operation of
Universities and Colleges to complete the
fund.
Will you not, by posting up this notice and
by making announcement personally and
through the college publications, give to lovers
of poetry among your Undergraduates the
opportunity of contributing one dollar each,
so that, without burden to anyone, your institution may be credited with the total amount,
which, it is hoped, will not be less than $50.
Checks should be made payable to the KeatsShelley Memorial Fund. The list will be
placed in the archives of the House.•
Respectfully yours,

ROBERT UNDERWOOD JOHNSON,
Secretary American Committee.
Care of The Century,
33 East 17th St., New York.

NEW FACULTY APPOINTMENT.
We were all very sorry to hear of Dr. Vos
leaving the University next year. His successor, who has been recently appointed, is
Dr. Robert Bruce Roulston. Dr. Roulston
graduated from Johns Hopkins in 1900; he
continued his work in German, and held a
Fellowship in 1902-1903. He also studied at
the University of Berlin (1904-1905), and
finally obtained his doctorate at Johns Hopkins
in 1906. Dr. Roulston has an extremely interesting personality, and his descriptions of
student-life in Germany are particularly vivid.
He has been head of the German department at
the Baltimore Country Schools for Boys for the
last two years, and has proved a great
favorite with his students.

A WORD ABOUT THE JUNIOR BANQUET
The NEWS-LETTER, being the publication
of the Undergraduates, feels that, in matters
concerning two of the classes, it should take
some 'definite position. At present there is a
question as to who shall pay for the damage
caused at the Junior banquet through the
interference of the Freshmen. As the Editorial
Board is comprised almost entirely of Juniors,
our opinion may be regarded with some suspicion, but we shall try to give the view which
occurs to us as indicating the only proper
course to take at the present time.
We will try to sum up briefly the facts in
the case: (1), The Juniors had rented the
hall, had several captive Freshmen seated at
the table and considered themselves in security.
(2), An employee of the hotel had been stationed at the door, instructed to admit Seniors
and Juniors only. (3), The Freshmen obtained admission because the door-keeper was
told by the Seniors to admit them as being
expected. (4), Without the protection and
interference on the part of the Seniors, no
fracas would have occurred. (5), The Seniors
certainly would not have acted as they did, if
the sentiment of their class had been against
so doing. (6), The Seniors probably protected and egged on the Freshmen because the
sentiment of their class was to act in this way.
(7), No damage would have been done if the
Freshmen had not made an attempt to rescue
their men by force. (8), The question as to
whether the policy of the Seniors was in
accordance with the traditions of the University is by no means certain.
Under these circumstances it is evident that
all the classes have been at fault in some particular: (1), The Seniors, for acting in away
which no other Seniors have done under
similar circumstances, and evidently causing
the damage by allowing the trouble to take
place. .(2), The Juniors, for holding captive
certain Freshmen, a fault which is perhaps
excusable, and (3), The Freshman, for making
an entry by force into a place where they had
no right to be.
It does not seem fair for the Juniors to pay
for the damage merely because they had rented
the hall; nor is it right for the Freshman to pay
for the entire loss, as they acted in a manner
perfectly natural under the circumstances.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

The Seniors, on whom the whole blame might
be shifted for the affair having ever taking
place at all, would refuse to pay $145 for an
indiscretion on the part of some of its members.
Under these conditions, what is the best
policy to adopt? It is very doubtful if any
one of the three classes either would or could
pay the full bill for damages. We suggest
that every Undergraduate he called on to pay
Eke amount of one dollar. Owing to the difficulty of collecting this sum from each man,
and since the breakage is due to the action of
representatives of all three classes, we suggest
that this amount be substracted from each
man's caUtion money. Those who are opposed
to this plan may make themselves audible at
the next class meeting.
Surely this is a plan which is, at least,
practical, and would tend to do away with any
ill-feeling between members of different classes
in a matter in which it is evident all have
made mistakes to a greater or less degree.
Someone once said: 'Those who dance should
play the fiddler." Seniors, Juniors and Freshmen all 'danced" on the night of the banquet.
Let everyone, then, join in to pay the fiddler.
Hopkins is too small to have any amount of
class squabbles. Let us avoid ill-feeling on
any subject.

MR.

ALAN CHliSNIW.

A NEW HONORARY FRATERNITY.
A circular issued by the National Secretary
of Delta Sigma Rho has been recently read by
one of the editors of this paper, and as the
object of this new intercollegiate honorary fraternity will probably be of interest to some
members of the University, an account of its
organization and purpose may not be amiss.
Delta Sigma Rho was founded on April 13,
1906, at Chicago. Its object is "to encourage
sincere and effective public speaking." No
person is elligable to membership until he has
actually participated in an intercollegiate contest of debate or of oratory. To quote from
the folder: "Many of the most ambitious,
energetic and capable men . . . . in college
devote much time to oratory and debate,
thereby sacrificing frequently an opportunity
to make football or baseball teams; to make
Phi Beta Kappa; to win scholarships and other
collegiate honors." It is to provide a reward
for such men that the new society has been
started. The writer of the "manifesto" at
hand is, perhaps, a little to confident in the
future glories of Delta Sigma Rho. Speaking
of the society he writes: "Wherever and
whenever men are looking for ability and
leadership, for cultivated minds and strong
wills, for initiative, energy and integrity,
hither they will turn first." That is pretty

MR. INRMANN J. HUGHIN.

strong. We have known the above qualities
to be the partial possession of men even who
did not wear the Key of Phi Beta Kappa!
Neverthelesss, the new society is to be commended to the investigation of all who are
interested in public speaking and debates.

By recent amalgamation with the Society of
Gamma Alpha the Alpha Chapter of Alpha
Delta Epsilon becomes the Johns Hopkins
University Chapter of the Gamma Alpha
Graduate Scientific Fraternity.
Gamma Alpha was organized at Cornell
University in the fall of 1899, and had also
placed a chapter at Chicago University.
Alpha Delta Epsilon was founded at Johns
Hopkins University in the fall of 1905 and
had a chapter at Dartmouth. The aims of
the two organizations were identical—that of
bringing .together in the various centers of
research graduate students and members of
the staff who were doing scientific work and
of promoting a true fraternal spirit among
them, and it therefore seemed best to all concerned to unite forces.
The society, though closely limited as to
membership, is wholly non-secret, and in nowise enters the field of any existing organization.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS—VIRGINIA
DEBATE.
The last of a series of three debates between
the Johns Hopkins University and the University of Virginia was held Friday, April 3,
in Madison Hall of the University of Virginia.
The question debated was,"Resolved, that
national banks should be permitted to issue,
subject to a tax and government supervision,
notes, based on their general assets."
After much dissatisfaction three judges were
finally obtained, who bore the responsibility
of rendering favor to whom favor was due,
honor to whom honor was due, and decision
to whom decision was due.
Virginia had the affirmative of the question
and was represented by :
Thomas S. Sattle, (college,) Flint Hill,Va.
Maurice Hirsh, (college,) of Houston, Tex.
LeRoy R. Fonville, (law,) of Burlington,
N. C.
H. Hadley Thurlow, as alternate, (law,) of
Buffalo, N. Y.
The Johns Hopkins team consisted of N.
Clyde Marvel, Robert N. McCauley, Arthur
H. Mann, and Allan H. Fisher as alternate.
Under the conditions imposed by the contract, each speaker was allowed a twelveminute set speech and a five-minute rebuttal.
President Alderman, of the University of Virginia, was presiding officer. Albert D. Hutzler,(J. H. U.,) and J. C. Hipp,(U. of Va.,)
were timekeepers.
Hopkins excelled in oratory and rebuttal,
but Virginia won.

"SIGNS OF SPRING."
When the days grow long and pleasant,
And the time drags slowly on,
The "studes" loaf in the alley
While the "quartette" sings a song.
Then someone on the "Campus"
Makes the nickles ring.
It is good to hear them,
Fof it's a sign of Spring.
Walter's shop is empty,
And has a lonesome air;
That's a sure sign, I tell you,
That Spring is in the air.
Hours are so long in 'lab,"
All studies make you sore.
That's another sure sign, I tell you,
That Spring has come once more.
When you go up to Gordon's
Some warm night about now,
The luscious mint julep
Will cool your heated brow.
Then, with the other fellows,
You make the windows ring;
By Jove! I tell you,
That a dead sure sign its Spring.

The result of last Monday's Freshman—
Junior game was not more than was to be
expected. The Freshmen had been practicing
faithfully for two or three weeks and had had
the advantage of two practice games. The
consequent team work and condition was more
than enough to overcome the little superiority
in individual playing the Juniors might have
had.
Great credit is due the Freshmen for their
performance, and in the same degree should
the Juniors feel their defeat. Had they displayed a little, just a little, teamwork to show
that they had made some attempt to work for
the game the defeat would not be so disgraceful.

HOPKINS, 6—NAVY, 1.
The game with the Navy was decidedly not
all that one could wish. From a Navy standpoint it was very creditable, but from our

standpoint it was not eminently so. Our fellows journeyed to Annapolis with the idea
that, as long as it was Navy's first game,
there wouldn't be much trouble scoring goals,
and there would be plently of glory for everyone. This idea, coupled with one or two
other factors, was instrumental in making the
loyal Hopkins rooters on the sidelines feel
anything but satisfied. Our team expected an
easy game and were fooled, for the way Navy
started off with a rush soon demonstrated the
fact that they were a bunch of fighters, with
the same Navy spirit.
The game showed that, while stick-work is
essential to a good lacrosse team, still a good
fighting spirit can go a long way toward
making up for defects in stick-handling.
These sailors were in the game from start to
finish, and completely surprised the fellows
from Baltimore. The goal scored by them
was a clean, well-deserved goal, and no fluke.
Their anxiety to play hard was, at times,
worked to disadvantage on their defense, for,
by their rushing so hard, our attack could
dodge almost at will. They have been quick
to learn, and if they only keep it up for a year
or so, Hopkins will have as hard a time to
defeat Navy as they do to lick Swarthmore.
Unfortunately, the field was rather small,

THE NEWS-LETTER.

TO ALGERNON CHARLES SW1NBURNE.
APRIL 5th, 1908.
Sovereign of song, a welcome today across the rolling sea
I send in greeting to you on this happy morn of Spring;
Another year has past away, and still we look in love to thee
As one who gives forth song and makes the wildernesses sing,
As one, who since his youth-time,
In gladness and in ruth-time,
In anger and in passion, in hate, in love, in praise,
Has given us full measure
Of unalloyed pleasure
By ceasely song and music through the full-time of his days.
The full three-score of years and ten rested on you a year ago,
Then from the corners four of all the world you beard
Our messages of reverence, from rich and poor, from high and low—
A message comprehended in a single, perfect word—
A word, whose meaning yearly,
Through all your lifetime clearly,
You have expounded to the world and placed all words above—
Which now in reverence duly
And admiration truly
I send to you—a perfect gift—a radiant message—Love!
Take this, my gift from o'er the seas, and in thy home among the Pines
Think for a moment of a heart which has a love for thee—
Who, midst the dreams of boyhood, in admiration, in these lines
Has written here his love for you, the Poet o'er the sea.
But though the sea divide us
There ever is beside its
One bond—here and in England—a bond we share among
Two nations far asunder;
And, yet, the broad seas under,
There runs the common, glorious tie—the bond of Shakespeare's tongue.
S. C. C.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

THE KEATS-SHELLEY MEMORIAL IN
ROME.
DOLLAR SUBSCR PTIONS INVITED FROM
UNDERGRADUATES.
March, 1908.

To the Professor of English Poetry:
The fund for the purchase of the Keats
House in Rome lacks about $1,500, which it
is desirable to raise at once. As Secretary of
the informal American Committee, which in
the death of Mr. Stedman has lost its. devoted
Chairman, I am inviting the co-operation of
Universities and Colleges to complete the
fund.
Will you not, by posting up this notice and
by making announcement personally and
through the college publications, give to lovers
of poetry among your Undergraduates the
opportunity of contributing one dollar each,
so that, without burden to anyone, your institution may be credited with the total amount,
which, it is hoped, will not be less than $50.
Checks should be made payable to the KeatsShelley Memorial Fund. The list will be
placed in the archives of the House.•
Respectfully yours,

ROBERT UNDERWOOD JOHNSON,
Secretary American Committee.
Care of The Century,
33 East 17th St., New York.

NEW FACULTY APPOINTMENT.
We were all very sorry to hear of Dr. Vos
leaving the University next year. His successor, who has been recently appointed, is
Dr. Robert Bruce Roulston. Dr. Roulston
graduated from Johns Hopkins in 1900; he
continued his work in German, and held a
Fellowship in 1902-1903. He also studied at
the University of Berlin (1904-1905), and
finally obtained his doctorate at Johns Hopkins
in 1906. Dr. Roulston has an extremely interesting personality, and his descriptions of
student-life in Germany are particularly vivid.
He has been head of the German department at
the Baltimore Country Schools for Boys for the
last two years, and has proved a great
favorite with his students.

A WORD ABOUT THE JUNIOR BANQUET
The NEWS-LETTER, being the publication
of the Undergraduates, feels that, in matters
concerning two of the classes, it should take
some 'definite position. At present there is a
question as to who shall pay for the damage
caused at the Junior banquet through the
interference of the Freshmen. As the Editorial
Board is comprised almost entirely of Juniors,
our opinion may be regarded with some suspicion, but we shall try to give the view which
occurs to us as indicating the only proper
course to take at the present time.
We will try to sum up briefly the facts in
the case: (1), The Juniors had rented the
hall, had several captive Freshmen seated at
the table and considered themselves in security.
(2), An employee of the hotel had been stationed at the door, instructed to admit Seniors
and Juniors only. (3), The Freshmen obtained admission because the door-keeper was
told by the Seniors to admit them as being
expected. (4), Without the protection and
interference on the part of the Seniors, no
fracas would have occurred. (5), The Seniors
certainly would not have acted as they did, if
the sentiment of their class had been against
so doing. (6), The Seniors probably protected and egged on the Freshmen because the
sentiment of their class was to act in this way.
(7), No damage would have been done if the
Freshmen had not made an attempt to rescue
their men by force. (8), The question as to
whether the policy of the Seniors was in
accordance with the traditions of the University is by no means certain.
Under these circumstances it is evident that
all the classes have been at fault in some particular: (1), The Seniors, for acting in away
which no other Seniors have done under
similar circumstances, and evidently causing
the damage by allowing the trouble to take
place. .(2), The Juniors, for holding captive
certain Freshmen, a fault which is perhaps
excusable, and (3), The Freshman, for making
an entry by force into a place where they had
no right to be.
It does not seem fair for the Juniors to pay
for the damage merely because they had rented
the hall; nor is it right for the Freshman to pay
for the entire loss, as they acted in a manner
perfectly natural under the circumstances.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

The Seniors, on whom the whole blame might
be shifted for the affair having ever taking
place at all, would refuse to pay $145 for an
indiscretion on the part of some of its members.
Under these conditions, what is the best
policy to adopt? It is very doubtful if any
one of the three classes either would or could
pay the full bill for damages. We suggest
that every Undergraduate he called on to pay
Eke amount of one dollar. Owing to the difficulty of collecting this sum from each man,
and since the breakage is due to the action of
representatives of all three classes, we suggest
that this amount be substracted from each
man's caUtion money. Those who are opposed
to this plan may make themselves audible at
the next class meeting.
Surely this is a plan which is, at least,
practical, and would tend to do away with any
ill-feeling between members of different classes
in a matter in which it is evident all have
made mistakes to a greater or less degree.
Someone once said: 'Those who dance should
play the fiddler." Seniors, Juniors and Freshmen all 'danced" on the night of the banquet.
Let everyone, then, join in to pay the fiddler.
Hopkins is too small to have any amount of
class squabbles. Let us avoid ill-feeling on
any subject.

A NEW HONORARY FRATERNITY.
A circular issued by the National Secretary
of Delta Sigma Rho has been recently read by
one of the editors of this paper, and as the
object of this new intercollegiate honorary fraternity will probably be of interest to some
members of the University, an account of its
organization and purpose may not be amiss.
Delta Sigma Rho was founded on April 13,
1906, at Chicago. Its object is "to encourage
sincere and effective public speaking." No
person is elligable to membership until he has
actually participated in an intercollegiate contest of debate or of oratory. To quote from
the folder: "Many of the most ambitious,
energetic and capable men . . . . in college
devote much time to oratory and debate,
thereby sacrificing frequently an opportunity
to make football or baseball teams; to make
Phi Beta Kappa; to win scholarships and other
collegiate honors." It is to provide a reward
for such men that the new society has been
started. The writer of the "manifesto" at
hand is, perhaps, a little to confident in the
future glories of Delta Sigma Rho. Speaking
of the society he writes: "Wherever and
whenever men are looking for ability and
leadership, for cultivated minds and strong
wills, for initiative, energy and integrity,
hither they will turn first." That is pretty

MR. INRMANN J. HUGHIN.

strong. We have known the above qualities
to be the partial possession of men even who
did not wear the Key of Phi Beta Kappa!
Neverthelesss, the new society is to be commended to the investigation of all who are
interested in public speaking and debates.

By recent amalgamation with the Society of
Gamma Alpha the Alpha Chapter of Alpha
Delta Epsilon becomes the Johns Hopkins
University Chapter of the Gamma Alpha
Graduate Scientific Fraternity.
Gamma Alpha was organized at Cornell
University in the fall of 1899, and had also
placed a chapter at Chicago University.
Alpha Delta Epsilon was founded at Johns
Hopkins University in the fall of 1905 and
had a chapter at Dartmouth. The aims of
the two organizations were identical—that of
bringing .together in the various centers of
research graduate students and members of
the staff who were doing scientific work and
of promoting a true fraternal spirit among
them, and it therefore seemed best to all concerned to unite forces.
The society, though closely limited as to
membership, is wholly non-secret, and in nowise enters the field of any existing organization.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS—VIRGINIA
DEBATE.
The last of a series of three debates between
the Johns Hopkins University and the University of Virginia was held Friday, April 3,
in Madison Hall of the University of Virginia.
The question debated was,"Resolved, that
national banks should be permitted to issue,
subject to a tax and government supervision,
notes, based on their general assets."
After much dissatisfaction three judges were
finally obtained, who bore the responsibility
of rendering favor to whom favor was due,
honor to whom honor was due, and decision
to whom decision was due.
Virginia had the affirmative of the question
and was represented by :
Thomas S. Sattle, (college,) Flint Hill,Va.
Maurice Hirsh, (college,) of Houston, Tex.
LeRoy R. Fonville, (law,) of Burlington,
N. C.
H. Hadley Thurlow, as alternate, (law,) of
Buffalo, N. Y.
The Johns Hopkins team consisted of N.
Clyde Marvel, Robert N. McCauley, Arthur
H. Mann, and Allan H. Fisher as alternate.
Under the conditions imposed by the contract, each speaker was allowed a twelveminute set speech and a five-minute rebuttal.
President Alderman, of the University of Virginia, was presiding officer. Albert D. Hutzler,(J. H. U.,) and J. C. Hipp,(U. of Va.,)
were timekeepers.
Hopkins excelled in oratory and rebuttal,
but Virginia won.

"SIGNS OF SPRING."
When the days grow long and pleasant,
And the time drags slowly on,
The "studes" loaf in the alley
While the "quartette" sings a song.
Then someone on the "Campus"
Makes the nickles ring.
It is good to hear them,
Fof it's a sign of Spring.
Walter's shop is empty,
And has a lonesome air;
That's a sure sign, I tell you,
That Spring is in the air.
Hours are so long in 'lab,"
All studies make you sore.
That's another sure sign, I tell you,
That Spring has come once more.
When you go up to Gordon's
Some warm night about now,
The luscious mint julep
Will cool your heated brow.
Then, with the other fellows,
You make the windows ring;
By Jove! I tell you,
That a dead sure sign its Spring.

The result of last Monday's Freshman—
Junior game was not more than was to be
expected. The Freshmen had been practicing
faithfully for two or three weeks and had had
the advantage of two practice games. The
consequent team work and condition was more
than enough to overcome the little superiority
in individual playing the Juniors might have
had.
Great credit is due the Freshmen for their
performance, and in the same degree should
the Juniors feel their defeat. Had they displayed a little, just a little, teamwork to show
that they had made some attempt to work for
the game the defeat would not be so disgraceful.

HOPKINS, 6—NAVY, 1.
The game with the Navy was decidedly not
all that one could wish. From a Navy standpoint it was very creditable, but from our

standpoint it was not eminently so. Our fellows journeyed to Annapolis with the idea
that, as long as it was Navy's first game,
there wouldn't be much trouble scoring goals,
and there would be plently of glory for everyone. This idea, coupled with one or two
other factors, was instrumental in making the
loyal Hopkins rooters on the sidelines feel
anything but satisfied. Our team expected an
easy game and were fooled, for the way Navy
started off with a rush soon demonstrated the
fact that they were a bunch of fighters, with
the same Navy spirit.
The game showed that, while stick-work is
essential to a good lacrosse team, still a good
fighting spirit can go a long way toward
making up for defects in stick-handling.
These sailors were in the game from start to
finish, and completely surprised the fellows
from Baltimore. The goal scored by them
was a clean, well-deserved goal, and no fluke.
Their anxiety to play hard was, at times,
worked to disadvantage on their defense, for,
by their rushing so hard, our attack could
dodge almost at will. They have been quick
to learn, and if they only keep it up for a year
or so, Hopkins will have as hard a time to
defeat Navy as they do to lick Swarthmore.
Unfortunately, the field was rather small,
